thread.title: Solomon Lew all smiggles as pens and pyjamas power Premier
thread.title_full: Solomon Lew all smiggles as pens and pyjamas power Premier

title: Solomon Lew all smiggles as pens and pyjamas power Premier
text:
Prices at Smiggle are on the rise. Photo: Adam McLean
If your kids are pestering for more pocket money these school holidays, they might just have a case after Solomon Lew's Premier Investments warned prices were on the rise, even at its colourful stationery chain Smiggle.
Premier has already shifted manufacturing for some of its products and used hedging arrangements to reduce the impact of the weakening Aussie dollar, chief executive Mark McInnes. Now the group moves to higher prices to bolster its profits.
Yet Mr McInnes said that while Premier would follow its rivals and increase prices, it would tread carefully to not deter customers.
Mark McInnes and Solomon Lew. Photo: Greg Briggs
"Customers should expect prices will increase as the dollar falls," he said.
Advertisement The Turnbull factor Despite this, Premier's chairman Solomon Lew was upbeat about consumer sentiment, which he said would improve as a result of Malcolm Turnbull's elevation to Prime Minister.
"I think reading between the lines, consumer sentiment will pick up, it's been at a low and I think we can look forward to a very positive Christmas," Mr Lew said.
Premier, which has a stable of retail brands, including kids favourite Smiggle, sleepwear chain Peter Alexander and the Portmans and Dotti clothing stores, unveiled a 20.7 per cent jump in net profit to $88.1 million on total sales of $946 million.
Online sales grew by 31 per cent in fiscal 2015, and 38 per cent in the second half of 2015. Premier plans to grow its online business to represent 10 per sent of sales by 2020.
The strong full-year result was powered by Premier's international expansion of the Smiggle brand, along with the opening of 14 new Peter Alexander stores.
UK expansion By Christmas, Smiggle will have 16 new stores trading in the UK, with plans to launch in Scotland and Wales next year.
There are eight more Peter Alexander store openings planned for the first half of 2016 as the company is targeting up to 15 new stores in Australia and New Zealand in the next two years.
The two popular brands offset a weaker performance by the company's fashion labels Jay Jays, Just Jeans and Jacqui E, however Premier said all its brands reported growth over the past financial year.
